sen.j: ここでは日本料理の丼物を紹介する。
sen.e: Here, descriptions of Domburimono, a Japanese dish, are made.
Here, descriptions of Donburimono, a Japanese dish, are given.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: Here, descriptions of a Japanese dish Donburimono are given.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 丼物（どんぶりもの、どんもの）とは、丼に盛った飯の上に具を載せた料理である。
sen.e: Domburimono (or Donmono) is a dish in which cooked rice is placed in a bowl and other ingredients are put on it.
Donburimono (or Donmono) is a dish in which cooked rice is placed in a bowl and other ingredients are set upon it.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: Donburimono (or Donmono) is a dish in which cooked rice is placed in a bowl with other ingredients on top.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 日本の伝統的な食とはやや趣を異にし、同時に上品に食べることが難しい。
sen.e: Its nature is slightly different from that of traditional Japanese dishes, and it is also difficult to eat the dish elegantly.
Its nature is slightly different from that of traditional Japanese dishes, and it's difficult to eat the dish in a refined manner.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: Its nature is slightly different from that of traditional Japanese dishes, and it's difficult to eat the dish elegantly.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 従って、庶民的な食事とみなされることも多い。
sen.e: Therefore, the dish is often considered an everyday dish.
Consequently, the dish is often considered an everyday dish.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: Consequently, the dish is often considered an inexpensive dish.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: B級グルメの代表格でもある。
sen.e: It is a typical dish of so-called Class B Gurume (inexpensive, large-in-quantity and tasty dishes)
It's a typical dish of so-called class B Gurume (dishes that are delicious, inexpensive and provided in abundant amounts).
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: It's a typical dish of what is called class B Gurume (dishes that are delicious, inexpensive and provided in abundant amounts).
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 日本食の中ではそれほど古い歴史をもつ食事形式ではない。
sen.e: Of the Japanese dishes, Donburimono is eaten in a style that is not so old.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Of the Japanese dishes, Donburimono is eaten in a style that is relatively new.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: Among the Japanese dishes, Donburimono is eaten in a style that is relatively new.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 最も古い丼物は鰻丼で19世紀初めに登場し、続いて江戸末期には深川丼がうまれたといわれている。
sen.e: It is said that the Unagi-donburi (Domburimono with roasted eel on cooked rice) introduced in the early 19th century is the oldest Domburimono and Fukagawa-donburi (with cooked shellfish as an ingredient) was produced next towards the end of the Edo period.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It is said that the Unagi-donburi (Domburimono with roasted eel on cooked rice) introduced in the early nineteenth century is the oldest Domburimono, and that Fukagawa-donburi (with cooked shellfish as an ingredient) was produced next toward the end of the Edo period.
sen.cmt: number
sen.e: It is said that the Unagi-donburi (Donburimono with roasted eel on cooked rice) introduced in the early nineteenth century is the oldest Donburimono, and that Fukagawa-donburi (with cooked shellfish as an ingredient) appeared next toward the end of the Edo period.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 『どんぶり』の語源は『慳貪』もしくは『つっけんどん』から来ているといわれ、忙しい時に素早く食べるための食事だった、とされる。
sen.e: It is said that the term of "Donburi" originated in "Kendon" (being mean) or "Tsukkendon" (being curt) and that Donburimono was a dish to eat quickly when being busy.
It is said that the term "Donburi" originated in "Kendon" (being mean) or "Tsukkendon" (being curt), and that Donburimono was a dish to eat quickly when one was busy.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: It is said that the term "Donburi" originated in "Kendon" (being mean) or "Tsukkendon" (being curt), and that Donburimono was a fast-food dish for a busy person.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 明治初期には牛丼や他人丼、1891年に鶏肉を卵でとじた親子丼が登場した。
sen.e: In the early Meiji period, "Gyu-don" (Donburimono with cooked beef on cooked rice) and "Tanin-don" (Donburimono with cooked beef and egg on cooked rice: literally, stranger Donburimono), and in 1891, "Oyako-don" in which chicken meat cooked with egg is placed on cooked rice was introduced.

In the early Meiji period, "Gyu-don" (Donburimono with cooked beef on cooked rice) and "Tanin-don" (Donburimono with cooked beef and egg on cooked rice; literally, stranger Donburimono) were introduced, and in 1891, "Oyako-don," in which chicken meat cooked with egg is placed on cooked rice, made its debut.
sen.cmt: punctuation
sen.e: In the early Meiji period, "Gyu-don" (Donburimono with cooked beef on cooked rice) and "Tanin-don" (Donburimono with cooked beef and egg on cooked rice; literally, stranger Donburimono) were introduced, and in 1891, "Oyako-don," in which chicken meat cooked with egg is placed on cooked rice appeared.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 大正時代1913年に(ソース)カツ丼が発表された。
sen.e: "Katsu-don" (Donburimono with cooked and sauced pork cutlet on cooked rice) was announced in 1913 of the Taisho period.
"Katsu-don" (Donburimono with cooked and sauced pork cutlet on cooked rice) was announced in 1913, during the Taisho period.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: Katsu-don (Donburimono with cooked and sauced pork cutlet on cooked rice) was introduced in 1913, during the Taisho period.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: （卵とじカツ丼は1921年とされるが定かではない。）
sen.e: (It is said that "Tamago-toji-Katsudon" (Donburimono with pork cutlet cooked with egg on cooked rice) was introduced in 1921, but it is not certain.
(It is said that "Tamago-toji-Katsudon" (Donburimono with pork cutlet cooked with egg on cooked rice) was introduced in 1921, but it isn't certain.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: (It is said that "Tamago-toji-Katsudon" (Donburimono with pork cutlet cooked with egg on cooked rice) was introduced in 1921, which remains uncertain.)
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。原文・訳文に閉じ括弧を付ける

sen.j: (詳しくは「カツ丼」の項目参照。）
sen.e: For more information, refer to "Katsu-don.")
For more information, refer to "Katsu-don.")
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: (For further details, refer to "Katsu-don.")
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。原文・訳文に開き括弧を付ける

sen.j: このように、丼ものの様式は日本で受容され、具を変えることにより次々と新種が生まれている。
sen.e: In this way, the dish style of Donburimono has been accepted in Japan, and many new Donburimono dishes have been devised one after another by changing the ingredients
In this way, the Donburimono style has been accepted in Japan, and new Donburimono dishes have been devised one after another by changing the ingredients.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: In this way, the Donburimono style has been accepted in Japan, and new Donburimono have been introduced one after another by changing the ingredients.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 一方アジア諸国ではカレーやナシチャンプルのようにごはんとおかずを同じ食器の上で混ぜながら食べるのは一般的である。
sen.e: On the other hand, in Asian nations, it is the general way of eating that cooked rice and other ingredients are mixed on a plate immediately before eating them, as when eating curry or Nasi campur.
On the other hand, in Asian nations it's the general way of eating that cooked rice and other ingredients are mixed on a plate immediately before eating them, as when eating curry or Nasi campur.
sen.cmt: punctuation
sen.e: On the other hand, in Asian nations it's the general way of eating that cooked rice and the side dish to accompany rice are mixed on a plate immediately before eating them, as when eating curry or Nasi campur.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 中華人民共和国では別に配膳されるが、おかずを御飯茶碗に載せながら食べるのが普通の食事作法である。
sen.e: In the People's Republic of China, cooked rice and cooked ingredients are served on separate bowls and/or plates, but it is the general table manners that, before you eat an ingredient, you put it once on cooked rice in your rice bowl.

In the People's Republic of China, cooked rice and cooked ingredients are served in separate bowls and/or on plates, but it's the convention of the table that, before you eat an ingredient, you put it over the cooked rice in your rice bowl.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: In the People's Republic of China, cooked rice and cooked side dishes are served in separate bowls and/or on plates, but it's the convention of the table that, before you eat the side dishes, you put it over the cooked rice in your rice bowl.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 日本人の意識では他人に頼まないと八宝菜をご飯にのせられない（中華丼の項参照）。
sen.e: Japanese do not dare to put shop suey on cooked rice by themselves but ask other person to do so (refer to chuka-don (bowl of rice with a chop-suey-like mixture on it)).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Japanese don't dare to put shop suey on cooked rice by themselves but will ask another person to do so (refer to chuka-don (bowl of rice with a chop-suey-like mixture on it)).
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: Japanese don't dare to put chop suey on cooked rice by themselves but will ask someone to do so (refer to chuka-don (bowl of rice with a chop-suey-like mixture on it)).
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: これに対し、中国人なら自分でのせて食べるであろう。
sen.e: On the other hand, Chinese would do so by themselves.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, Chinese would do so by themselves.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: However, Chinese people would do so by themselves.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 日本において、中華料理の麻婆豆腐や蟹玉と、御飯の組み合わせの麻婆丼、天津飯などとを別の料理として認識している。
sen.e: In Japan, for example, each of the combination of cooked rice and the Chinese dish of Sichuan style bean curd (tofu & ground pork spicy taste and that of cooked rice and Chinese dish with fried egg and crab is recognized as an independent different dish, Mabo-don or Tehshin-don, respectively.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In Japan, for example, each of the combinations of cooked rice and the Chinese dish of Sichuan-style bean curd (tofu and ground pork spicy taste and that of cooked rice and Chinese dish with fried egg and crab) is recognized as an independent different dish, being either Mabo-don or Tehshin-don, respectively.
sen.cmt: grammar, punctuation
sen.e: In Japan, for example, the combination of cooked rice and the Chinese dish of Sichuan-style bean curd (tofu) and ground pork of spicy taste (Mabo-tofu), and the combination of cooked rice and Chinese dish with fried egg and crab (Kanitama) is recognized as independent of Mabo-don (cooked rice and Mabo-tofu) and Tehshin-don (cooked rice and Kanitama), respectively.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: しかしながら、この現象は、文化の異なる例えば中国人には奇異に映るかもしれない。
sen.e: However, such a phenomenon might be felt strange to Chinese.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Such a phenomenon might appear strange to the Chinese.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: Such a custom might appear strange to the Chinese.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: しかし、こういった日本の食事作法から丼物が生まれたことは偶然の産物であるが新しい調理方法を生み出すきっかけとなった。
sen.e: However, although Donburimono produced from such Japanese table manners by chance, the introduction of it gave the opportunity of developing new cooking methods.
However, although Donburimono originated through such Japanese table manners by chance, its introduction provided the opportunity to develop new cooking methods.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: However, although Donburimono originated from such Japanese table manners by chance, its introduction provided the opportunity to develop new cooking methods.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

tit.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 上の具と下の飯を交互に食べるのが好ましいとされる。
sen.e: It is said that it is preferable to eat cooked rice and the ingredient placed on it alternately.
It is said that it is preferable to eat cooked rice and the ingredient placed on it alternately.
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: It is said that it is preferable to eat cooked rice and the side dish placed on it alternately.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 旧来の日本の食事は、主食である飯とおかずが別々に配膳され、それを一口ずつ口に運び口内で調味するという様式を基本としている。
sen.e: In Japanese meals in the past, it was basic that cooked rice, the staple food, and side dishes were served separately, and a portion of rice and a portion of the side dishes are put into the mouth separately to be mixed and tasted within the mouth.

Previously, in Japanese meals it was basic that cooked rice, the staple food, and side dishes were served separately, and a portion of rice and a portion of the side dish would be placed in the mouth separately to be mixed and tasted.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: Previously, in Japanese meals it was basic that cooked rice (the staple food) and side dishes were served separately, and a portion of rice and a portion of the side dish would be put in the mouth separately to be mixed and tasted.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 今でもおかずを御飯にのせて食べることを行儀作法の点から問題視されることは日本では多い。
sen.e: In Japan, even today, it is often considered problematic to put food of side dishes on cooked rice.
In Japan, even today, it's often considered problematic to put food from a side dish on top of cooked rice.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: In Japan, even today, it's often considered rude to put a side dish on top of cooked rice and eat it.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 丼物はこの様式を崩し、おかずと御飯が一緒となっているので、簡便な食事として好まれている。
sen.e: Donburimono destroyed this style of eating, and is likened as a simple meal because cooked rice and side dishes are placed together.
Donburimono did away with the old convention, and it's considered a simple meal because cooked rice and side dishes are placed together.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: Donburimono deviates from the old convention, and it's considered a simple meal because cooked rice and side dish are placed together.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 具にかかる汁、タレをご飯が吸収し、ご飯自体の味わいが変化することも、丼物の魅力の一つである。
sen.e: It is also one of the attractive feature of Donburimono that soup or sauce for the ingredients is absorbed by the cooked rice, changing the taste of the cooked rice itself.
It is also an attractive feature of Donburimono that the soup or sauce for the ingredients is absorbed by the cooked rice, thus changing the taste of the cooked rice.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: It is also an attractive feature of Donburimono that the soup or sauce for the side dish is absorbed by the cooked rice, thus changing the taste of the cooked rice.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: ご飯に汁がなじむ効果などを求め、蓋をして出される例が多い。
sen.e: To make soup be absorbed thoroughly by the cooked rice, the bowl of Donbrimono is often served with the lid placed on it.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In order for the soup to be absorbed thoroughly by the cooked rice, the bowl of Donburimono is often served with the lid placed on it.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: In order that the soup can be absorbed thoroughly by the cooked rice, the bowl of Donburimono is often served with the lid placed on it.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: これによって短時間だけ蒸すとおいしく食べられるとする向きもある。
sen.e: Some people say that the Donburimono becomes more tasty by streaming the contents of the bowl for a while in this way.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Some people say that the Donburimono becomes tastier by steaming the contents of the bowl for a while in this way.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: Some people say that the Donburimono becomes tastier by steaming the contents of the bowl for a while with the lid.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: しかし、天ぷらなどは蒸さない歯触りが喜ばれる例もある。
sen.e: However, in some Donburimono, for example, Domburimono with Tenpura (deep-fried fish and vegetables) as its ingredient, not steaming is favored because eating the un-steamed ingredient gives the eater a good feeling to the teeth.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, in some Donburimono, such as Domburimono with Tempura (deep-fried fish and vegetables) as its ingredient, steaming isn't favored because eating the non-steamed ingredient is a pleasant sensation against the teeth.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: However, in some Donburimono, such as Donburimono with Tempura (deep-fried fish and vegetables) as its side dish, steaming isn't favored because eating the non-steamed side dish is a pleasant sensation against the teeth.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 様々である。
sen.e: Therefore, it can be said that there is no consistent rule for serving Donburimono.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Thus it can be said that there is no consistent rule for serving Donburimono.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: Thus it can be said that there is no consistent rule for serving Donburimono.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 料理屋によっては蓋をしないで出す例もある。
sen.e: Some restaurants serve Donburimono with no lid.
Some restaurants serve Donburimono without a lid.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: Some restaurants serve Donburimono without a lid.
sen.cmt: 修正なし
